activityStory.sectionTitle: Chengdu IFS: Where Fashion, Art, and Culture Converge

sectionBody.bodyParagraph: Located in the heart of Chunxi Road—Chengdu’s most vibrant commercial district—Chengdu International Finance Square (IFS) is more than a luxury shopping mall. It’s a modern icon that brings together art, architecture, and lifestyle. Whether you’re a shopper, photographer, foodie, or casual explorer, IFS offers a snapshot of urban Chengdu at its most dynamic.

activityStory.sectionTitle: The Giant Panda on the Rooftop

sectionBody.bodyParagraph: One of IFS’s most famous features is “I Am Here”, a giant panda sculpture climbing the building’s façade. Created by artist Lawrence Argent, the sculpture has become a beloved symbol of Chengdu and a viral photo spot on social media. The playful panda, peeking over the edge of the building, adds a whimsical touch to the luxury complex.

activityStory.sectionImageCaption: “I Am Here” Panda Sculpture on IFS

sectionBody.bodyParagraph: Chengdu IFS houses over 600 brands, including Chanel, Hermès, Louis Vuitton, and Apple. The interior is sleek and modern, with art installations, digital screens, and landscaped terraces. It’s not just a shopping mall—it’s a lifestyle destination. Even if you’re not buying, the window displays and ambiance are worth experiencing.

activityStory.sectionTitle: Food and Leisure Above the City

sectionBody.bodyParagraph: Beyond shopping, IFS offers rooftop gardens and dining options that overlook the skyline. Popular restaurants, cafés, and even tea houses are scattered across multiple levels, making it a great place to relax. The outdoor plaza is often home to exhibitions and pop-up events.

Chengdu IFS is the city’s perfect mix of contemporary life and cultural flair. With a giant panda climbing its walls, sky-high cafés, and endless shopping and dining, it’s more than a mall—it’s a symbol of Chengdu’s modern personality. Don’t forget to snap a photo with the panda—you’re here now, just like him.

activityTitle: Exploring Marco Polo's footprints: Chengdu Anshun Bridge

sectionBody.bodyParagraph: In the long flow of history, travel has always been a powerful way to experience culture—and Anshun Bridge in Chengdu is a perfect example. Even Marco Polo, one of the earliest “travel bloggers,” praised this bridge in his writings, calling attention to its beauty and cultural richness. Let’s explore the story of this ancient landmark that continues to charm visitors today.

activityStory.sectionTitle: A Bridge Between Past and Present

sectionBody.bodyParagraph: Located in the heart of Chengdu, Anshun Bridge stretches across the calm Jin River, blending centuries-old history with modern elegance. Originally built during the Ming Dynasty, it once served as a vital transport hub and symbol of economic activity. From the bridge, visitors can enjoy scenic river views and experience a deep sense of cultural heritage.
Marco Polo described it vividly: marble pillars on both sides, a red-tiled wooden roof, and intricate patterns showcasing the architectural brilliance of its time.

In ancient times, Anshun Bridge was a vibrant marketplace. Craftspeople displayed their skills, merchants called out their prices, and a central tax point underscored the bridge’s role in trade. As Marco Polo wrote, it was not just a bridge—but a lively center of daily life.
Even today, the bridge remains a popular gathering spot for both tourists and locals.

activityStory.sectionImageCaption: Anshun bridge over Jin River illuminated at night, Chengdue, Sichuan, China

sectionBody.bodyParagraph: Though rebuilt multiple times, the current Anshun Bridge remains a cultural landmark. By day, it welcomes photo-loving tourists; by night, it glows with colorful lights reflecting in the water—a dreamlike sight. Take a stroll, listen to the gentle flow beneath, and feel the echoes of the past still alive around you.

activityTitle: Spend the day at the Sydney Opera House

activityStory.sectionTitle: Be Moved by A Live Performance

sectionBody.bodyParagraph: When it comes to iconic performance venues, the Sydney Opera House is high on the list. Take a seat in the Concert Hall, one of the world’s most sought-after performance spaces, and marvel at the intricate ceiling and grand stage. The Opera House hosts all types of performing art. Comedy, opera, dance, musical theatre and more – the choice is yours.

activityStory.sectionImageCaption: Sydney Opera House, Sydney, New South Wales

activityStory.sectionTitle: Watch A First Nations Light Show

sectionBody.bodyParagraph: The Sydney Opera House sits on the traditional lands of the Gadigal people. Meaning ‘water light’ in the language of the Gadigal people, Badu Gili is a nightly event that sees a spectacular projection light up the white walls (also called 'sails') of the iconic venue. Grab the best view from the top of the Monumental Steps and watch Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander stories brought to life.

activityStory.sectionImageCaption: Sydney Opera House, Sydney, New South Wales

sectionBody.bodyParagraph: We’re not sure which is better at Bennelong – the exceptional menu or the jaw-dropping view. The restaurant is housed within the sails of the Sydney Opera House and champions distinctly Australian flavours (think mud crab and finger lime). Dining alongside the sparkling harbour only adds to the refined ambience.

What you see on stage is only half the story. The Sydney Opera House offers a range of tours that bring you behind the scenes of the venue’s history, architecture and show production. True theatre enthusiasts can even land a walk-on role to experience opera from the performer’s perspective. Don a custom-fitted costume and step into the spotlight for one unforgettable night.

activityStory.sectionTitle: See The Sails From All Angles

sectionBody.bodyParagraph: Boasting some of the world’s most beautiful architecture, the Sydney Opera House doesn’t have a bad angle. Seek out unique vantage points on an adventure tour with epic views. Take a seaplane over the harbour to spot not only the Opera House but the Sydney Harbour Bridge and city skyline as well. A kayak tour will have you paddling up close for a spectacular view. Whichever tour you choose, it’s bound to create a bucket list memory.

activityStory.sectionImageCaption: Sydney Opera House, Sydney, New South Wales

sectionBody.bodyParagraph: Located in Pudong, Shanghai Disneyland is the first Disney resort in mainland China and the largest Disney park in Asia. Opened in 2016, it blends classic Disney storytelling with Chinese cultural elements, creating a one-of-a-kind experience for families, couples, and solo travelers alike.

At the heart of the park stands the Enchanted Storybook Castle—the tallest, largest, and most interactive castle in any Disney park worldwide. Unlike other parks, this castle represents all Disney princesses, not just one, and offers attractions, dining, and even a boat ride beneath it.

activityStory.sectionImageCaption: Enchanted Storybook Castle, the centerpiece of Shanghai Disneyland

sectionBody.bodyParagraph: • TRON Lightcycle Power Run – A futuristic, high-speed roller coaster.
• Pirates of the Caribbean: Battle for the Sunken Treasure – A jaw-dropping boat ride with cutting-edge visuals.
• Roaring Rapids – A thrilling river adventure through mysterious mountains.
• Soaring Over the Horizon – A breathtaking hang-glider simulation over global landmarks.
• Alice in Wonderland Maze – A beautiful outdoor walk-through perfect for all ages.
From Western fast food to Chinese cuisine, the park caters to all tastes. Try:
• Royal Banquet Hall – Inside the castle, offering fine dining with Disney character encounters.
• Wandering Moon Teahouse – Beautiful Chinese-style eatery with rice bowls, noodles, and soups.
• Remy’s Patisserie – Ideal for quick snacks and sweets.

activityStory.sectionTitle: Don’t Miss the Night Parade & Fireworks

sectionBody.bodyParagraph: End your day with the “Ignite the Dream” fireworks show and Mickey’s Storybook Express Parade. The castle lights up with dazzling projections and music—a magical finale that leaves everyone smiling.

activityTitle: 8 Things To Know Before Visiting Bondi Beach

sectionBody.bodyParagraph: Bondi Beach is a surfing haven, offering waves for beginners and pros alike. The southern end attracts experienced surfers with stronger breaks, while the northern end has gentler waves and is safer for swimming. Local surf schools offer lessons daily if you’re keen to learn.

The Bondi Icebergs Club, with its stunning ocean pool perched above crashing waves, is one of Sydney’s most photogenic spots. Established in 1929, it’s perfect for a swim or a meal with a view — and yes, non-members are welcome.

Don’t miss the 6-kilometre Bondi to Coogee walk. It weaves along dramatic cliffs, past beaches like Tamarama and Bronte, and offers panoramic ocean views and cafes for pit stops. It’s free, scenic, and one of Sydney’s best outdoor activities.

Bondi’s dining is as fresh as its sea breeze. Think beachfront cafes, organic brunches, and buzzing bars. Head to Hall Street and Curlewis Street for standout spots like Bills, Gelato Messina, and Bondi’s famous fish and chips.

Sundays bring the Bondi Markets, where you’ll find artisan goods, vintage fashion, and street eats. In spring, “Sculpture by the Sea” transforms the coast into a clifftop art gallery — an unforgettable way to see Bondi.
Bondi is accessible via several direct buses, including the popular 333, 380, and 381 routes from the city and Bondi Junction. Parking can be tricky on weekends, so public transport is your best bet.
From the boutique QT Bondi to hostels and short-term rentals, there’s an option for every budget. Book early during summer and holidays, as Bondi accommodation fills fast.

activityStory.sectionTitle: 8. Safety First – Swim Between the Flags

sectionBody.bodyParagraph: Bondi is patrolled daily by lifeguards, including the stars of Bondi Rescue. Always swim between the red and yellow flags, and check the surf conditions before diving in. The north end is generally calmer and more family-friendly.

activityTitle: A Journey to China’s Timeless Wonder

activityStory.sectionTitle: A Journey to China’s Timeless Wonder

sectionBody.bodyParagraph: Badaling (八达岭) is the most famous and best-preserved section of the Great Wall of China, located about 70 km northwest of central Beijing. As the first part of the Wall to open to the public in 1957, it offers breathtaking views, wide walking paths, and deep historical significance.
• Historic Importance: Built during the Ming Dynasty (1505), Badaling was a military stronghold that protected Beijing from northern invasions.
• Accessibility: Wide stone steps and handrails make it the most visitor-friendly section—suitable even for seniors and children.
• UNESCO Recognition: Badaling helped earn the Great Wall its World Heritage status in 1987.

activityStory.sectionImageCaption: Sunrise observed from the Great Wall

sectionBody.bodyParagraph: • Hike the Wall: Choose between the North route (steeper with higher views) and South route (gentler and less crowded).
• Cable Car or Funicular: For a less strenuous experience, take a cable car up and hike down.
• Scenic Photo Spots: Tower 8 and Tower 12 offer sweeping panoramic views.
• Comfortable walking shoes
• Sunscreen and a hat
• Water and light snacks
• Layers for changing weather
Tip: Avoid wearing slippery shoes—the stone steps can be uneven.

The Badaling Great Wall offers one of the most accessible and majestic ways to experience China’s ancient history. Whether you climb the steep towers or glide up by cable car, it’s a must-visit for every traveler in Beijing.
